column1: Will there be a lethal confrontation between the national military forces, militia, and/or law enforcement personnel of Taiwan and the People's Republic of China before 15 December 2020?
column6: ['Security and Conflict']
No; this will not happen.
timing is running out
Downgrading for time...only about a week remains and no reporting suggests unusually heightened tensions.
Short timeline, COVID, and no news suggesting increased tensions right now.
2 weeks left
https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/24/world/asia/taiwan-china-trump-biden.html

There is no extraordinary activity between Taiwan and China at this time. It seems highly unlikely a lethal confrontation will occur in the next couple weeks. Furthermore, the US State Department recently reaffirmed its support for Taiwan's "freedom and independence," (https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/policy/defense-national-security/us-affirms-taiwans-freedom-and-independence-despite-chinas-sovereignty-claims), a fairly clear signal of U.S. support to Taiwan which should dissuade China from taking overt action. My only hesitation from an even lower forecast value is the sheer number of actors included in the question.
Adjusting for time.
with the remaining time, my estimation of the chance has fallen to just under half a percent so rounding down to 0.

Use of weapons on targets above the waterlines has been oked for the PLA Navy. <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/_2uXnPuwGsw" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>
0.01%, rounding down to 0
Still too many provocations not to rule out a mid-air near miss.
-1 on time passed.

There appears to be a low chance of purposeful lethal confrontation between the PRC and Taiwan between now and 15 Dec. Numerous articles have pointed to the intensifying overt relationship between Taiwan and the US, and the worsening relationship between the PRC and the US. To attack Taiwan may be a bet the PRC doesn’t want to make in the next 30 days in fear of bringing the US into the mix (and Japan, Korea, and Guam, and other states with US basing). The economic ties between Taiwan and the PRC still appear fairly substantial; neither side likely wants to deny their state the benefits of those relationships.

China's New Pressure on Taiwan in the South China Sea - Foreign Policy Research Institute https://www.fpri.org/article/2020/11/chinas-new-pressure-on-taiwan-in-the-south-china-sea/ Mon, 16 Nov 2020 15:42:54 GMT
Updated 20201123
Passage of time.
Possible. China is watching to see if there's a 'moment'. More likely there will be a clash with China and India but this is one other alternative.
Less likely due to time passed and no change in political situation noticed

Any deaths between military forces (militia and LEO's included) will be purely accidental in nature, most likely because of one or both sides having aggressive pilots involved in a mid-air collision similar to the Hainan Island incident between the PLAAF fighter and the American Recon plane twenty years ago.

US Speeds Arms Sales for Taiwan as Island Revamps China Strategy - VOA Asia https://www.voanews.com/east-asia-pacific/us-speeds-arms-sales-taiwan-island-revamps-china-strategy Fri, 06 Nov 2020 14:15:00 GMT

I figure if China hopes to invade Taiwan at any time within the next 3 years it will be within the next 3 weeks. So I give it a 1 in 33 chance China will invade over the next 3 years. Give it zero chance after Feb 1st.
Worst case scenario among some analysts is China invades Taiwan during a protracted undecided US election under the theory the executive will be too distracted by the election outcome to respond.

China is gaining influence over Taiwan through soft power means. With their increasing control over international institutions to shape the global view, growing economic advantage over the region, this means that Taiwan would lack the regional and international support required. If a lethal confrontation happens, it would likely be instigated by a Taiwanese group acting outside the control of the Taiwanese government.

Anti-ship missile sale could frustrate a Chinese invasion of Taiwan - Business Insider - Business Insider https://www.businessinsider.com/sale-of-missiles-to-taiwan-could-frustrate-a-chinese-invasion-2020-10 Wed, 28 Oct 2020 14:41:32 GMT
Decreasing because of time gone by
Decent background on this and broader South China Sea... https://www.nippon.com/en/in-depth/d00627/

Increasing my forecast to take into account the recent provocations by the PRC (especially aerial intrusions) plus an increase in inflammatory language from the CCP (https://www.spytalk.co/p/is-china-preparing-to-attack-taiwan). The possibility of an accidental death by collision has increased. The likelihood of an actual invasion is less clear. There are so many countervailing arguments to factor into any decision that it seems unlikely (but not impossible) the General Secretary and Standing Committee will decide to act. Time is on their side.

Two great reads on the worsening Taiwan-China situation: https://www.economist.com/china/2020/10/22/chinas-half-loving-half-threatening-pitch-to-taiwan-doesnt-work https://www.nbcnews.com/news/china/tiny-taiwan-caught-middle-u-s-china-battle-supremacy-n1244521

China is occupied in constant transgressions of the US defined median line between the mainland and Taiwan that it refuses to recognise. The CCP has been vocal in that its aim is to recover the island and return it to China and appears to be conducting psychological warfare in preparation for a full-scale invasion. According the you tube clip the window of opportunity in 2020 has passed due to weather conditions that prevail at this time of year but will reopen March 2021. I will suggest that a lethal confrontation in 2020 has limited value to China that would raise, even further, awareness in the US and Taiwan to increase preparedness in terms of weaponry. It will be a different scenario in 2021.

Good overview of the current situation: "2020 has seen Taiwan's unexpected resurgence on the international stage ... Beijing has responded with anger and shows of force, including military drills and numerous incursions into Taiwanese airspace ... 'Taiwan is one of those flash points that has never flashed,' writes Michael Schuman for The Atlantic. But now, says Schuman, the conditions appear to be ripe for possible conflict." https://www.axios.com/china-taiwan-conflict-4e3cd357-22de-463f-851c-4275884b0b6e.html
Passage of time; -1% every 15 days.

Excellent article by The Economist, with some relevant tidbits: "Last year Xi Jinping, China’s leader, declared unification to be an 'inevitable requirement for the historical rejuvenation of the Chinese nation'. The PLA has stepped up pressure on Taiwan in recent months, sending warplanes across the 'median line' that long served as an unofficial maritime boundary and holding large naval drills off several parts of Taiwan’s coast ... China’s defence budget, merely double Taiwan’s at the end of the 1990s, is now 25 times greater ... American intelligence officials do not think that China is about to unleash this firepower. The PLA’s amphibious fleet has grown slowly in recent years. China has never held even a single exercise on the scale that would be required for a D-Day-type campaign." https://www.economist.com/asia/2020/10/10/defending-taiwan-is-growing-costlier-and-deadlier
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-taiwan-politics-idUSKBN26U1QT

Although Taiwan is rebuilding its military and has a resolute leader in Tsai Ing-wen power it remains unlikely that China and Taiwan will engage in a lethal confrontation before December 15, 2020, because at this time the “PRC appears willing to defer the use of military force as long as it considers that unification with Taiwan could be negotiated over the long-term and the costs of conflict outweigh the benefits.

Although Taiwan is rebuilding its military, it's doubtful that either China or Taiwan would engage in a lethal confrontation in the next 60 days.
Dropping down, seems unlikely and time has passed.

"Taiwan is not pursuing formal diplomatic ties with the United States for now, but there is 'a lot' of room to further strengthen relations, Foreign Minister Joseph Wu said in an interview after unprecedented visits by two senior U.S. officials ... In August, U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar traveled to Taiwan, and last week Under Secretary of State Keith Krach visited the island. They were the highest ranking U.S. officials to travel to Taiwan since Washington cut formal diplomatic relations with Taipei in 1979 to establish ties with Beijing ... The cozier relationship between Washington and Taipei has angered Beijing. While Krach was in Taiwan, China ordered dozens of military planes to make forays across the median line that divides the Taiwan Strait, in a bid to rattle Taipei." https://www.npr.org/2020/09/22/915818283/formal-ties-with-u-s-not-for-now-says-taiwan-foreign-minister
Currently no change, but continued airspace violations by the PLAAF could lead to an accident and escalation in the near term.

China is behaving more aggressively and hardening the language and increased incursions into Taiwan airspace by its air force. China has for the first time gained a technological superiority over Taiwan in its military capability. One potential conflict could be for the PLA to take over the Taiwan islands of Kinmen Matsu and Penghu as a test of capability, Taiwanese resolve and world reaction. A Chinese invasion of Taiwan would be bloody and expensive, but they would ignore a backlash if it consisted only of rhetoric and would shrug off International isolation as the world cannot distance itself from China economically (yet). Xi Jinping has indicated his impatience to resolve the Taiwan issue. The resolve of the US would be tested as to react militarily could lead to war and to ignore it would be to accept the authority of the Chinese. Both dangerous. A precursor to military action would be heightened cyberattacks on the institutions of Taiwan and China has been increasing those. Hong Kong has been subjugated and Taiwan remains the last piece to make China, one. The only probability here is that China will eventually attempt (and probably succeed) in gaining control over Taiwan. The only question is when? The timeline is quite short and I propose there will be a sure but steady build up over a period of time.
Updating 1%-ish over aircraft provocations.
It is likely we'll see more and more provocations by Chinese aircrafts in the future [1] - possibly on similar frequency levels of "interaction" by Chinese and Japanese aircrafts currently [2,3].

China would likely prefer to deal with Biden (consistency). Winnie the Pooh unlikely to be too provocative prior to election results. That does allow a month window before close of question, however. Still keeping it low.

"Multiple Chinese aircraft flew across the mid-line of the Taiwan Strait and into Taiwan’s air defence identification zone on Friday and Saturday, causing Taiwan to scramble jets to intercept ... The exercises took place as U.S. Undersecretary for Economic Affairs Keith Krach was in Taipei, the most senior State Department office to come in four decades ... Further friction seems likely as Taiwan and the United States continue to deepen relations, with Taiwan angling for a free trade agreement." https://www.reuters.com/article/us-taiwan-china-idUSKCN26B06I

Increased cooperation and coordination between Tiawanese and American Governments is straining already tense Sino-American relations. Increased political tensions tend to lead to increased military action in the form of drills and movement of forces to areas adjacent to potential battle areas. Increased proximity of military forces in a highly charged political atmosphere tends to lead to an accidents that could spark a potential conflict.

Revising slightly upward on recent news: "Taiwan sounded the alarm over China conducting large-scale joint air and naval exercises inside its air defence buffer zone, a move Taipei denounced as a 'severe provocation' and a threat to regional peace and stability ... At a rare press conference called on Thursday night, Taiwan’s defence ministry said almost two dozen Chinese military aircraft and seven naval ships had operated between 7am and noon on Wednesday and Thursday in an area between Pratas, a Taiwan-controlled atoll in the South China Sea, and Taiwan’s south-western coast ... The drill confirms concerns in Taipei that the People’s Liberation Army would ratchet up military pressure closer to Taiwan’s borders once the coronavirus crisis receded in China. A Taiwanese former senior military officer said the Chinese move was the most serious threat to Taiwan’s security since 1996, when Beijing fired missiles into waters just north and south of Taiwan." https://www.ft.com/content/9bf1c039-3222-4aa7-be37-6f01afc41ef2
increased tensions

This is more of a possibility than is commonly appreciated as President Trump could recognise Taiwanese sovereignty in a bid to stoke high USA-China cold war tensions before the November 2020 US election. His recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel and meeting with Kim Jong Un show a capacity for shock moves like this. Unfortunately this could easily spiral out of control due to his lack of nuanced understanding of the regional politics; China is a pragmatic police state with a long term view and no apparent appetite for conflict but this would represent a line that could not be crossed without retaliation.

Say civilization collapses and you are short the stock market. If you were short the market, you were right, but you won't to get paid. If China and Taiwan come into lethal conflict, good chance I won't care what my Brier score is.

Adjusting back down. China has a superior force staged to invade, but has to cross the straight. Taiwan has nearly all it's male population in the reserves which could be called up. The official US position is in support of China's one China policy, but I tend to think that the United States would support Taiwan in an invasion. And I think China believes that too. and Chinese and Taiwan troops are not likely to casually run into each other like China and India might. So the only possibility for a fatality would be a full-on invasion. Also, China has other enemies in the region that might take advantage.
War games cause me to increase from my rock bottom forecast.

Increasing my likelihood due to the recent buildup of amphibious tanks and mobile rocket launchers at the China border and due to the recent live-fire exercises by China. This may be just to appease a certain faction within China though.

This is my take on this question: The national military forces, militia, and/or law enforcement personnel of the PRC and the Republic of China do not come face to face like, say, those of China and India, China and the Philippines or the US and Iran. Any provocation in the Taiwan Strait by either side would be extremely serious in the light of China's threat to retake Taiwan, and will almost inevitably draw in the US. Therefore, it is a very long shot. Due to its perceived strength from the Covid-19 crisis vis-a-vis other nations, there is not enough pressure on CPC leadership to do anything drastic with regards to Taiwan before Dec 15th this year.

Increasing likelihood due to China building up amphibious tanks and missile launchers near Taiwan. https://www.zerohedge.com/geopolitical/china-mobilizes-invasion-craft-coast-near-taiwan-amid-high-level-us-meeting-taipei
Down, passage of time.

"U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar will lead a delegation to Taiwan on Sunday to meet with senior Taiwanese officials in a rare high-profile visit to the island. Planned discussions will focus on the global response to the COVID-19 pandemic, but the visit comes as tensions between Washington and Beijing have rapidly escalated. It is expected to provoke a strong reaction from China ... In advance of Sunday’s visit, China threatened to take 'strong countermeasures in response to the U.S. behavior.' ... The meeting is also expected to involve discussions on the broader U.S.-Taiwanese relationship." https://foreignpolicy.com/2020/08/07/u-s-officials-to-hold-high-level-talks-with-taiwan-as-tensions-with-china-worsen/
Given economic downturn China probably does not want a big war at the moment.
Lowering 1%.
Lowering. Doubt China would want the instability or cost of attacking Taiwan. They might be tempted due to US confusing policies.

Once the U.S. cuts the supply of U.S. dollars to Hong Kong, the latter's foreign exchange reserves will dry out to the point that its linked exchange rate system can no longer function, causing the Hong Kong dollar to depreciate as well as the Renminbi. When this happens, foreign companies will withdraw from the Special Administrative Region with their capital.

Having said that, if there is a chaotic outcome to the US presidential election, China might take its chance. Also, a small but deadly confrontation such as that which occurred on the Indian border cannot be ruled out.

Okay, @DelapsusAngelus below points out an article ( https://www.voanews.com/east-asia-pacific/voa-news-china/china-sends-8-military-planes-taiwan-airspace-analysts-see-move ) that says the Chinese did eight of these military aircraft scrambles toward Taiwan in June, twice as many as I was expecting on a monthly basis when I made my last prediction (on May 10, https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1031675 ). I am accordingly doubling my estimate, from 1% to 2%.
Raising current forecast as this indicates there is some provocation recently:

Why would there be a lethal exchange between Taiwan and the PRC and to whose advantage would it be? No advantage to Taiwan who have been preparing for invasion for the last 70 years against overwhelming odds. Both sides are armed with first class weaponry. China wants to regain Taiwan into the authority of the mainland for two reasons: a) China’s determination that Taiwan is a part of and belongs to the mainland and b) China does want a militarised island lying off its coast with and supported by potential enemies. A military solution to Chinese demands would prove to be expensive both in lives and economics and localised skirmish resulting in a lethal outcome would not be helpful. A dispute involving fishing boats is assumed to not involve the military. A more likely scenario would be a cyber war attacking Taiwan’s systems of government, industry and business with an emphasis on persuading the populace of its errors would provide a non-lethal battle. Given the sensitivity and volatility of the region, a legal confrontation is unlikely as great care will be taken to avoid any accidental outbreaks. Therefore, avoiding 0% as a possibility, I propose 5% chance of a lethal outbreak before 15th December 2020.
Most likely after November 3 (if DT victory) but HK the main focus now and likely for rest of 2020.
India issue makes this unlikely. With HK just starting it's political vacuum, makes it very unlikely.
Deaths on the India border + further aggression in Hong Kong. Perhaps Taiwan is next. I think this merits a +1% increase in my forecast.

Probability of an accidental death during a confrontation ticking up because of US naval exercises in SCS. Taiwan has more experience than other players in facing off against the PRC so I estimate their likelihood as lower.

For example, Chinese Flankers recently entered Taiwan' ADIZ, three US carrier groups are now operating in the Western Pacific, the US Navy has increased transits through the Taiwan Strait etc.(multiple sources, but Lawfare has the best summary: https://www.lawfareblog.com/water-wars-pandemics-great-power-competition-sea). Fatalities are always possible, especially accidental as a result of provocative behaviour.

Hard to believe that the PRC will think there will be a better time than about Aug-Sep. A wavering US president, a increasingly vigorous push back from Congress, US arms shipments yet to arrive in great numbers, Corona virus distracting the world, economic considerations for all but Xi and a strengthening resistance from Taiwan. It may be now or wait until well after Xi is gone for the PRC to do its most important piece of business.
Taiwan will do everything in their power to prevent it, but China might force the circumstances.

China has strong interest in adding resources of additional territory. ( land and sea) The objectives of increasing their access to additional space and territory cannot be accomplished with a lethal skirmish involving people. They do not want to add more non-Han population and/or more reluctant Chinese controlled citizens. Continuing border and territory claim creep is a more strategic play for them.
Very unlikely because China has far easier targets to hit first, but if there is, it will be by accident
I believe that China will have its hands full dealing with issues in Hong Kong and will not be focused on Taiwan for some time
Lethal means at least 1. Volatile situation.
Report China entered Taiwan airspace.
I trust geord359 forecast
It has to happen. It would happen in any oppressed society.

From what I can tell there have been 2 lethal conflicts since the PRC was formed in 1949. Although both Taiwan and China were involved in the Vietnam war on opposing sides there was no direct conflict from what I have read. It's around 6 months until this question resolves so I'd say the base rate is about 1-2%. I have listed below factors which I believe could make conflict more or less likely:
Error in my previous forecast, was intending to write 9, not 49.

China have not been in a lethal confrontation in the last 20 years involving territorial disputes, so it would seem unlikely. However, In confrontations over territory since 1950, there have been 8 that have involved the PRC. In seven out of eight there have been lethal confrontations, so there is still a chance of this happening.

The current environment of interior confusion in US politics may be seen as an opportunity for PRC to get a hold on Taiwan. If they want to integrate Taiwan into the PRC for real at all, now is the time the least resistance is to be expected.

I think the PRC would be willing under some circumstances, but with the Covid backlash and US pressure they may keep provocations and pressure non-military. It is interesting to see that they have not made any new moves on Canada in light of the recent loss in court on the Meng extradition file.

Tough question. The longer 'the West' is distracted by the virus, the more likely China will start pushing in that direction. While I fully expect Hong Kong to be 'absorbed' into mainland China within the next year (possibly year-end), Taiwan is still a different animal. Unfortunately, I do not expect the USA (or EU) to actually come to Taiwan's aid (though morally, it/they should) in the event of a Chinese invasion (look what they did, well didn't do, after Russia, a regional power at best, invaded more than one of it's prior USSR member states.

I will be watching this situation closely. China recently has ordered the military to increase their preparedness. This does not necessarily mean that they are looking to go to war, but there is some possibility they look at the global instability at the current moment as an opportunity. Details have emerged about a Chinese training compound that is a mockup of the Taiwanese Presidential Palace. I do not think an invasion/war of that scale is coming this year though. I think if anything does happen, China would be using the situation as a test.
